stories.text:
Hey everyone, my name is Michael. After working in the data space for several years I realized that it was still a huge gap in the marketing analytics market. Marketers weren’t taking their data to its full advantage. Missing on many growth opportunities.

In my personal case, I was tired of wasting time on dashboards and graphics. I wanted a straightforward way to understand everything that happens on my website so I can always make the most accurate decisions.

So, that's why I made this platform called Narrative BI (https://www.narrative.bi/) to give marketers the chance to leverage marketing analytics data. The app turns complex data into actionable narratives. This means anyone can understand their data. Even if they are complete beginners.

But it's not only for beginners. Data experts can also save time in analyzing data thanks to the narratives the platform automatically generates.

At the moment it’s integrating with UA and GA4 and I will be releasing the Google Ads and Facebook Ads integrations in the next few months.

You can try it out for free and give your feedback or roast it in the comments section. Just connect your UA or GA4 account and you'll start getting narratives in 5 minutes.
stories.title: A no-code platform that turns complex data into actionable narratives
Esqa, tiny tool to verify the search qualities of the Elasticsearch indices

stories.text:
Code review is important, but I find it's often a momentum-killer. A few things can happen after you open a PR:

* Nobody reviews it for days because everyone is busy working on their own stuff. This is likely because code review isn't as rewarded as pushing code ("I implemented X" sounds better in a standup than "I reviewed a bunch of PRs yesterday").

* You end up in an endless back and forth with one or more reviewers (e.g. push-review-fix-push-review-fix-push-review...). If this occurs over the course of days, the "fix" portion becomes an interruption where you have to remember the context of the changes, make the changes, then submit them.

These are the two instances I can think of off the top of my head, but if you have other examples and strategies for combating them, I'd love to hear them.
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you keep code reviews from taking forever?
